title: What is a Stack?
contentText: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) rule. The most recently added element is the first one removed.

title: Core Operations: Push, Pop, Peek
contentText: Push adds an element to the top, Pop removes the top element, and Peek reads the top element without removing it.

title: Common Stack Use Cases
contentText: Stacks are used for function call management, undo/redo features, browser history, and expression evaluation.

title: Advantages of Stack
contentText: Stack operations are simple and efficient, typically O(1) for push and pop. They are excellent for managing temporary states and backtracking.
